G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the undisputed amount in controversy is less than $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2A.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2A, as the property at issue is located in Chelsea, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, has a statutory and contractual duty to ensure that the leased premises, including the common areas, are safe and secure and to protect the tenant’s right to the quiet enjoyment of the property pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease in Massachusetts.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This is a concurring/dissenting opinion by Justice Quirico that focuses on implied warranty/habitability and statutory code-based obligations, not on the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The excerpt expressly disagrees with the majority’s broader implied warranty approach and instead would limit the landlord’s implied obligations to compliance with housing codes; it does not discuss or establish that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every Massachusetts residential lease. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: A breach occurs when a landlord substantially interferes with the tenant’s lawful use and enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court’s quiet enjoyment analysis explicitly defines a breach as a “serious interference” that “substantially impairs the character of the leased premises,” and applies that standard to the landlord’s failure to address criminal activity in the common areas, which prevented tenants from using sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas. This directly aligns with the idea that a breach occurs when the landlord substantially interferes with the tenant’s lawful use and enjoyment of the premises through acts or omissions.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … [I]f the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.

Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959,.raw_text: Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985)
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that security deficiencies resulting in tenant harm breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breaches of the implied warranty of habitability, violations of G.L. c. 93A, and a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the factual basis described concerns defective heating equipment and unsanitary habitability conditions, not security deficiencies. The court does not mention locks, building security, or similar issues, nor does it tie any security-related deficiency to the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that security deficiencies resulting in tenant harm breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendants were also found, with respect to the condition of the apartment, to have violated the implied warranty of habitability (see Boston Housing Authy. v. Hemingway, supra) and the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see c. 186, § 14), but recovery was allowed on c. 93A as covering the ground of the other two claims and being the largest of all.”

Lyon v. Broomfield Gardens Apartments, I.raw_text: Lyon v. Broomfield Gardens Apartments, Inc., 1994 Mass. App. Div. 49, 50
Lyon v. Broomfield Gardens Apartments, I.proposition: The obligation to address known property defects is a fundamental landlord duty.
Lyon v. Broomfield Gardens Apartments, I.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns enforcement of a promissory note given in connection with a real estate purchase and issues of agency and illegality in contract. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, duties regarding property conditions, or any obligation to address known property defects. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that addressing known defects is a fundamental landlord duty.
Lyon v. Broomfield Gardens Apartments, I.relevant_excerpt:
Appellate review by this Division entails consideration of actual trial court rulings in the light of applicable law and on the basis of an established report of evidence and proceedings. Speculation as to possible trial court rulings based on unreported evidence forms no part of the appellate process.

Moreover, even assuming arguendo that there was evidence at trial that the plaintiff and defendant conspired to obtain a first mortgage loan from Dime by illegal means, such illegality would not automatically render unenforceable the defendant’s promissory note to the plaintiff, as both parties appear to assume.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws protect against intentional or negligent acts by landlords that cause tenant harm.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related tenant-protection statutes as part of a scheme designed to protect tenants from harms caused by landlords’ failure to maintain safe and sanitary housing, regardless of whether the landlord’s conduct is intentional or merely reckless, and at least potentially negligent. It holds that § 14 does not require malicious intent and covers at least reckless interference with quiet enjoyment, and emphasizes that unsanitary conditions harm tenants whether the landlord acts intentionally, negligently, or innocently, thereby supporting the proposition that Massachusetts statutes protect tenants from harmful landlord conduct beyond purely intentional acts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The objectives of these statutes go beyond deterrence of intentional wrongdoing; unsanitary conditions in an apartment cause harm to the occupants whether the landlord has acted intentionally, negligently, or innocently… Our analysis of the language and history of § 14… leads us to conclude that malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.”

Brown v. Laconia Dev. Co., 1984 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Brown v. Laconia Dev. Co., 1984 Mass. App. Div. 133, 134
Brown v. Laconia Dev. Co., 1984 Mass. Ap.proposition: Failure to repair critical security measures constitutes a “willful or negligent” interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Brown v. Laconia Dev. Co., 1984 Mass. Ap.case_name: Consolidated Rail Corp. v. Hallamore Motor Transportation, Inc.
Brown v. Laconia Dev. Co., 1984 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The case is an interstate freight charges dispute and does not involve landlord‑tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or any issue about security measures in a residential or commercial property. The opinion concerns consignee liability for freight charges under the Interstate Commerce Act and 49 U.S.C. § 10744. It therefore does not address, much less establish, that failure to repair critical security measures constitutes a willful or negligent interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Brown v. Laconia Dev. Co., 1984 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: "The sole issue in this case is whether the trial court erred in finding the defendant liable for freight charges to the plaintiff. Hallamore contends that since it was not the owner of the crane components and that it did not agree to be the consignee, it is not responsible for the payment of the tariff charges. We find no error."
